Jose Antonio LOPEZ, Petitioner,
v.
Alberto R. GONZALES, Attorney General.
No. 05-547.
Supreme Court of United States.
Argued October 3, 2006.
Decided December 5, 2006.
*627 Patricia G. Mattos, Mattos Law Office, St. Paul, MN, Robert A. Long, Counsel of Record, Theodore P. Metzler, Covington & Burling LLP, Washington, DC, for Petitioner.
Paul D. Clement, Solicitor General, Counsel of Record, Peter D. Keisler, Alice S. Fisher, Assistant Attorneys General, Edwin S. Kneedler, Michael R. Dreeben, Deputy Solicitors General, Patricia A. Millett, Assistant to the Solicitor General, Donald E. Keener, John Andre, Thomas M. Gannon, Margaret Perry, Bryan S. Beier, Attorneys, Department of Justice, Washington, D.C., for respondents.
Justice SOUTER delivered the opinion of the Court.
The question raised is whether conduct made a felony under state law but a misdemeanor under the Controlled Substances Act is a "felony punishable under the Controlled Substances Act." 18 U.S.C. § 924(c)(2). We hold it is not.

I

A
The Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) defines the term "aggravated felony" *628 by a list that mentions "illicit trafficking in a controlled substance ... including a drug trafficking crime (as defined in section 924(c) of title 18)." § 101(a)(43)(B), as added by § 7342, 102 Stat. 4469, and as amended by § 222(a), 108 Stat. 4320, 8 U.S.C. § 1101(a)(43)(B).
